Introduction

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is an adverse reaction to heparin therapy characterized by a drop in platelet count during treatment.  There are 2 types of HIT, differing in onset, clinical course, and severity of disease.  The clinically significant form, type 2 HIT, is an immune-mediated, life-threatening disease associated with a paradoxical prothrombotic state.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Heparin is an anticoagulant that is administered intravenously to prevent thrombus formation.  Heparin potentiates the action of antithrombin III (

figure 1
), which inactivates thrombin and several coagulation factors, including factor Xa.  As a result, fibrinogen cannot be converted to fibrin, limiting fibrin clot formation.



In approximately 5% of patients, heparin causes an adverse reaction characterized by thrombocytopenia.  There are 2 forms of HIT (

).



Type 1 HIT is a non-immune-mediated disorder in which heparin induces platelet aggregation that results in thrombocytopenia within 1-4 days of initiation of therapy.  With a platelet nadir >100,000 mm3, thrombocytopenia resolves spontaneously within days of onset, even with continued heparin therapy.  This form of HIT does not cause clinical symptoms.



The remainder of this article focuses on the clinically significant type, type 2 HIT.



Type 2 HIT is an immune-mediated disorder in which the interaction between heparin and activated platelets induces formation of an autoantibody through the following series of events (

figure 2
):



  • Under normal circumstances, activated platelets release platelet factor 4 (PF4), a protein that binds and inactivates heparin to promote coagulation.
  • As heparin binds PF4, it induces a conformational change that exposes a neoantigen.
  • The immune system recognizes the neoantigen on the heparin-PF4 complex and forms complex-specific IgG antibodies known as HIT antibodies (
    figure 3
    ).
  • When the HIT antibodies bind, this forms an antibody-heparin-PF4 complex.  The Fc portion of the HIT antibody binds Fc receptors on the platelet surface, resulting in further platelet activation and PF4 release, further inducing HIT antibody production. 


This process of platelet activation and HIT antibody production ultimately results in:



  • Thrombocytopenia:  The antibody-coated platelets are removed by macrophages in the reticuloendothelial system (eg, spleen), causing mild-to-moderate thrombocytopenia (rarely <20,000/mm3) with minimally increased risk of hemorrhage. 
  • Arterial and venous thrombosis:  HIT antibodies activate platelets, resulting in platelet aggregation and release of procoagulant factors.  Therefore, patients are at increased risk of thrombosis despite being thrombocytopenic.  Venous thrombosis in the lower extremities, heart, and skin (at the site of heparin injection) is most common.  Arterial thrombosis may occur in the heart, limbs, or central nervous system.


Risk factors for developing HIT include:



  • Perioperative status:  patients undergoing cardiopulmonary bypass or vascular surgeries are at higher risk.
  • Unfractionated heparin use:  associated with higher risk than low-molecular-weight heparin.
  • Female sex:  females are at higher risk than males, likely because other autoimmune conditions occur in a greater frequency in females than males.


Of note, a small percentage of the general population naturally produce antibodies that bind PF4-heparin complexes but do not cause platelet activation or a prothrombotic state.

Clinical presentation



Patients with type 2 HIT (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
) generally develop signs and symptoms (eg, thrombocytopenia, thrombosis) 5-10 days after initiation of therapy.  If untreated, type 2 HIT can lead to life-threatening complications (eg, stroke).  Examples of thrombotic manifestations include:



  • Arterial thrombus:  can cause acute ischemia with limb pain and diminished pulses.
  • Venous thrombosis:  can cause limb pain and edema.  Venous thrombosis can lead to pulmonary embolism with sharp chest pain that worsens with inspiration (ie, pleuritic chest pain), tachypnea, and decreased breath sounds.  An embolus in the right lower lobe can cause pain that radiates to the epigastrium and right upper quadrant.
  • Skin necrosis:  patients who receive heparin subcutaneously (eg, enoxaparin) may develop skin necrosis at the injection site.


Although patients are thrombocytopenic, hemorrhage is uncommon.  Of note, although type 2 HIT usually manifests 5-10 days after heparin initiation, it can occur earlier (sometimes <1 day) in patients previously exposed to heparin (eg, patients with end-stage renal disease who receive unfractionated heparin routinely with hemodialysis).  Acute systemic anaphylactoid reactions (eg, tachycardia, hypotension, dyspnea) following heparin administration may also occur.

Diagnostic evaluation



Serial laboratory testing (eg, complete blood count, coagulation studies) should be obtained while patients receive heparin.  Patients receiving heparin therapy have a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).  Although the inhibition of factor Xa and thrombin (part of the final common pathway) should also prolong the PT, the reagent used to perform the PT assay has a heparin-neutralizing agent.  Therefore, patients receiving heparin therapy usually have a normal PT.



HIT should be suspected if the platelet count declines â‰¥50% or if the patient develops signs or symptoms of thrombosis within 10 days of initiating therapy.  The likelihood of type 2 HIT is calculated using the 4 Ts score (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
), which includes the following:



  • Thrombocytopenia:  platelet count declines â‰¥50%, with a nadir of 30,000-60,000/ÂµL. 
  • Timing:  symptom onset within 5-10 days (no prior heparin exposure) or â‰¤1 day (recent prior heparin exposure) of therapy initiation.
  • Thrombosis:  includes new thrombosis, progressive thrombosis, or skin necrosis.
  • AlTernate causes:  no other etiology of thrombocytopenia is present or likely.


A 4 Ts score of â‰¥4 indicates an intermediate probability of type 2 HIT, and confirmatory HIT antibody testing should be performed, as follows:



  • Immunoassays (eg, ELISA):  are highly sensitive for the detection of antibodies against PF4-heparin complexes.  However, these tests cannot distinguish clinically significant antibodies (ie, present and activate platelets) from clinically insignificant antibodies (ie, present but do not activate platelets).
  • Functional assays (eg, serotonin-release assay [gold standard]):  detects whether PF4-heparin antibodies can activate platelets to cause HIT.  These tests are more specific for the diagnosis of HIT but have a longer turnaround time.


Imaging may be required to identify thrombotic complications (eg, venous doppler ultrasonography for deep venous thrombosis, CT for pulmonary embolism).

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of HIT includes other conditions that cause thrombocytopenia:



  • Decreased platelet production (eg, malignancy, medication or toxin exposure):  these conditions cause bone marrow failure and are usually associated with other cytopenias (eg, anemia, leukopenia).  Unlike HIT, thrombosis is not expected. 
  • Increased platelet destruction
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC):  a consumptive coagulopathy with systemic activation of coagulation pathways.  DIC typically occurs secondary to an underlying condition (eg, sepsis, severe trauma).  Similar to HIT, thrombocytopenia and thrombosis occur in DIC.  However, DIC is associated with hemorrhage and findings of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (eg, schistocytes).  In addition,  DIC shows prolongation in both PT and aPTT.
    • Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP):  is characterized by immune-mediated platelet destruction.  Although thrombocytopenia occurs in both ITP and HIT, ITP is not associated with thrombosis.  Very low platelet counts (eg, <20,000/ÂµL) with increased risk of hemorrhage is more likely in ITP than in HIT.
    • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP):  results from decreased levels of von Willebrand factor-cleaving protease ADAMTS13.  The classic presentation of TTP is the pentad of fever, thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, renal insufficiency, and neurologic dysfunction.
    • Hypersplenism:  refers to splenic platelet entrapment that may lead to thrombocytopenia but not thrombosis like that seen in HIT.

Management



Because type 2 HIT is life-threatening, empiric treatment should be initiated when clinical suspicion is high or when the 4 Ts score indicates an intermediate or high probability of the diagnosis (

figure 4
).  Treatment should not be delayed while awaiting laboratory confirmation.  Management includes:



  • Discontinue heparin:  All heparin products (including heparin flushes) should be discontinued immediately.  Because HIT antibodies recognize the neoantigen (which only forms in the presence of heparin), discontinuing heparin halts the platelet activation process.
  • Non-heparin anticoagulation:  Therapeutic anticoagulation with an alternate (ie, non-heparin) anticoagulant should be initiated due to the risk of thrombosis associated with HIT (
    figure 5
    ).  This may include:
    • Intravenous agents (eg, direct thrombin inhibitors [eg, argatroban, bivalirudin]):  These agents directly inhibit thrombin and do not require antithrombin-III for their action.  Fondaparinux, a synthetic version of the active pentasaccharide of heparin that does not interact with PF4, is also an option that may be used during pregnancy.
    • Direct oral anticoagulants (eg, direct thrombin inhibitors like dabigatran, direct factor Xa inhibitors like rivaroxaban, apixaban).
  • Initial avoidance of warfarin:  Because patients with HIT are prothrombotic, initial therapy with warfarin by itself is contraindicated because the rapid decrease in protein C levels that normally occurs during warfarin initiation can worsen the risk of thrombosis.  Patients with newly diagnosed HIT who were already on warfarin therapy should undergo reversal with vitamin K.  If warfarin is necessary due to an underlying condition, it may be safely initiated after the platelet count recovers to â‰¥150,000/mm3 and the patient is stable on nonheparin anticoagulation (which should be continued until the INR is therapeutic).


Serial platelet counts and coagulation studies should be obtained.  Following a diagnosis of HIT, patients should be anticoagulated for a few months, particularly if thrombosis occurred.  HIT antibodies are generally short-lived (2-3 months) and usually do not demonstrate an anamnestic response during heparin rechallenge.  However, due to the life-threatening nature of the condition, patients who develop type 2 HIT are advised to avoid all forms of heparin in the future in order to prevent recurrence.  Unfractionated heparin, low-molecular-weight heparin, heparin flushes for arterial lines, and heparin-coated catheters should all be avoided, and a "heparin allergy" should be listed in the medical record.



Although patients are thrombocytopenic, abnormal bleeding is rare in HIT.  Should there be clinically significant hemorrhage, platelet transfusions may be considered.

Prognosis



HIT-associated thrombosis can lead to significant morbidity and mortality (eg, stroke, myocardial infarction, limb loss).  If untreated, the mortality rate can be as high as 20%.  However, prompt diagnosis and early intervention can prevent these complications.

Prevention



HIT may be prevented by minimizing heparin exposure (eg, reducing duration, using low-molecular-weight heparin).  Post-operative patients, especially those undergoing cardiopulmonary bypass, should be closely monitored for thrombocytopenia.

Summary



Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) (

) is an adverse reaction to heparin therapy characterized by thrombocytopenia and a paradoxical prothrombotic state.  There are 2 types of HIT, differing in onset, clinical course, and severity of disease.  The clinically significant type, type 2 HIT, is an immune-mediated, life-threatening disease that is associated with thrombosis.  Early recognition, cessation of heparin, and initiation of alternative anticoagulation are essential to preventing thromboembolic complications and death.
